title_sort: kate a. evans to walt whitman, 2 august 1877
title: Kate A. Evans to Walt Whitman, 2 August 1877
text: Low Gap. Mendocino Co.,CaliforniaAug. 2. 1877Walt WhitmanMy beloved.A pioneer in the redwood forest salutes you, greets you with love sincerest and best. embraces you with her whole being, as the one chief among men and altogether lovely."This is no bookWho touches this, touches a man"I feel it. I know it.Nothing that I ever read so filled me with joy and gladnessSitting solitary in the forest, bathed in the warm sunlight with the cool breeze whispering to me, I know that we are akin and am thankful. I take the kiss you give. I know it was especially for meYou will take my kisses and love as from me that knows you and can never forget youI have received so much that I must make some return be it ever so little.John Burroughs more than any oneanyone that I know, fitly expresses my thought of you. I love him for it.I have never met any oneanyone that seemed to have the faintest understanding of you so I keep you all to myself locked in my heart of hearts.Kate A. Evans.from the Californian Kate Evans (? rather gushing) Kate A. Evans to Walt Whitman, 2 August 1877
